description: From Latin vacuum (“an empty space, void”), noun use of neuter of vacuus (“empty”), related to vacare (“be empty”).

entries.meaning: A region of space that contains no matter.
(colloquial, only pluralized as "vacuums") A vacuum cleaner.
The condition of rarefaction, or reduction of pressure below that of the atmosphere, in a vessel, such as the condenser of a steam engine, which is nearly exhausted of air or steam, etc.
examples: a vacuum of 26 inches of mercury, or 13 pounds per square inch

entries.meaning: (physics) A spacetime having tensors of zero magnitude.
An emptiness in life created by a loss of a person who was close, or of an occupation.
An exercise in which one draws their abdomen towards the spine.

verbs.description: vacuum (third-person singular simple present vacuums, present participle vacuuming, simple past and past participle vacuumed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clean (something) with a vacuum cleaner.

examples: Synonyms: (British) to do the hoovering, (British) to hoover

entries.meaning: (transitive, databases) To optimise a database or database table by physically removing deleted tuples.
